title: Look at background: it's a handwritten letter dated July 2, 1850 and is addressed to George Stokes, ...

attachments.displayName:
Look at background: it's a handwritten letter dated July 2, 1850 and is addressed to George Stokes, and just below the word 'manifolds' is the name of the author of this letter where it's written,"Your's very truly - William Thomson" and look at the expression below, you must be familiar with this, this's Stokes' Theorem. Isn't it? Yes, this is the famous letter of Sir William Thomson (Lord Kelvin) to Sir George Stokes where he first asked about his observation that was later to be known by Stokes' Theorem. One of the best book I have ever read in my life, and truly deserve admiration like the very Spivak's Calculus.

Shared by David

object.content:
Look at background: it's a handwritten letter dated July 2, 1850 and is addressed to George Stokes, and just below the word 'manifolds' is the name of the author of this letter where it's written,"Your's very truly - William Thomson" and look at the expression below, you must be familiar with this, this's Stokes' Theorem. Isn't it? Yes, this is the famous letter of Sir William Thomson (Lord Kelvin) to Sir George Stokes where he first asked about his observation that was later to be known by Stokes' Theorem. One of the best book I have ever read in my life, and truly deserve admiration like the very Spivak's Calculus.

Shared by David
it'd be an honor to read it someday
